pull.title: [API BREAK] Use rfc6979 as default nonce-generation function
pull.body:
Builds on top of #162, but also provides a safe default when not specifying a nonce generation function explicitly.

This means incorporation of a SHA256 / HMAC / RFC6979 implementation inside libsecp256k1. It's an increase of around 10 kilobytes of object size on x86_64, which I think is acceptable, despite it being likely code duplication (as callers already need to compute hashes too).

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body: Also, rfc6979 is painfully slow. It takes >50k CPU cycles to compute the nonce here, while the rest of the signing process takes around 180k cycles.

Compared the HMAC-SHA256 and RFC6979 implementations to those in Bitcoin Core. Didn't notice any flaws in the port. Also tested the SHA256 implementation and ran some crude [benchmarks](https://gist.github.com/aalness/577c7a6da1e669a07db9) out of curiosity.

I really like having this as the default. Much less foot-shooting-off potential.

events.message: [API BREAK] Use a nonce-generation function instead of a nonce
Use rfc6979 as default nonce generation function

events.body: (ut)ACK  (will also test, but I don't see any reason to wait on merging it)

issue.title: Use deterministicGenerateK from secp256k1
issue.body:
Hi.
Nonce generation per RFC6979 [was implemented in the secp256k1](https://github.com/bitcoin/secp256k1/pull/163) so [this JS function](https://github.com/wanderer/secp256k1-node/blob/master/index.js#L16) is no longer needed.

issue.title: Deterministic signatures RFC6979
issue.body:
Changing ECDSA signatures to be deterministic according to [RFC6979](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6979) in order to more easily write tests and compare implementations between Radix libraries.

Both JS and Swift library use deterministic Signatures. Now we can compare Signatures across libraries which is very advantageous.

Wether signatures should be deterministic or not can be controlled via a boolean flag. For now defaulted to `false`, and only used in unit tests.

# Used by
- [Bitcoin](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/163)
- [Ethereum](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/3561/files)
- [Ledger](https://github.com/LedgerHQ/nanos-secure-sdk/blob/master/include/cx.h#L233)

# Security Implications
[Read security section in RFC](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6979#section-4), exerpt:
```
Deterministic (EC)DSA shows how to achieve the
   security characteristics of a standard DSA or ECDSA signature scheme
   while removing the need for a source of strong randomness, or even
   any source of randomness, during signature generation.
```

Awaiting response on [my tweet](https://twitter.com/AlexCyon/status/1108718737459433472) to the legend DJB (Dan J Bernstein).
